concepts.unlisted_label: Chapter IIIA, Industries (Development and Regulation) Act, 1951

issues.text: Whether the order dated November 8, 1955 is a lawful order, as it fulfils the essential requirements of section 18A of the Industries (Development and Regulation) Act, 1951 (specifically, whether the Central Government could form the opinion that the undertaking was being managed in a manner highly detrimental to public interest)?

anchor.surface_text: 1 the order of November 8, 1955, is not a lawful order, as it does not fulfill one of the essential requirements of s. 18A of the Act under which it purports to have been made

issues.text: Whether section 18A of the IDRA authorises the extension of the period of the order dated November 8, 1955 by the amending order dated November 7, 1956, and whether such extension complies with the requirements of section 21 of the General Clauses Act?

anchor.surface_text: 2 even assuming that the order was a good order when it was made, s. 18A of the Act does not authorise an extension of the period during which the order is to remain in force, in the manner in which the extension was made on November 7, 1956, and such extension did not comply with one of the essential requirements of s. 21 of the General Clauses Act, No. X of 1897

issues.text: Whether the impugned orders are bona fide, given the appointment of Shri Kedar Nath Khetan as authorised controller despite his involvement in disputes?

anchor.surface_text: and 3 in any event, the order is not a bonafide order in that the Central Government appointed the very person who was mismanaging the undertaking, who was one of the parties to a pending dispute, and against whom an order of injunction had been passed by a Court of competent jurisdiction.

issues.text: Whether petitioner No. 1 was legally competent to represent petitioner No. 2 (the company)?

anchor.surface_text: In conclusion, it may be stated that on behalf of the authorised Controller a preliminary objection was also taken that petitioner No. 1 was not legally competent to represent petitioner No. 2.

issues.text: Whether the conditions in section 18A(1)(b) of the IDRA (investigation under s.15 and opinion of detrimental management) relate to the period when management is vested in the owner prior to takeover?

anchor.surface_text: If these ss. 15, 16 and 18A, are read together, as they must be read, then it becomes at once clear that the condition as to the management of the industrial undertaking in a manner highly detrimental to the scheduled industry concerned or to public interest relates in its true scope and effect to a period when the management of the industrial undertaking is in the hands of its owner

arguments.claim: The order dated November 8, 1955, is not a lawful order as it does not fulfill the essential requirement of s.18A(1)(b) that the undertaking is being managed detrimentally, since the authorised controller was already in charge.

anchor.surface_text: 1 the order of November 8, 1955, is not a lawful order, as it does not fulfill one of the essential requirements of s. 18A of the Act under which it purports to have been made

arguments.court_reasoning: Conditions in s.18A(1)(b) relate to period when management vested in owner; materials existed for govt opinion due to ongoing disputes and litigation.

arguments.claim: Even if original order valid, s.18A does not authorise extension of period as done on Nov 7, 1956, and it does not comply with s.21 General Clauses Act requirements.

anchor.surface_text: and 3 in any event, the order is not a bonafide order in that the Central Government appointed the very person who was mismanaging the undertaking, who was one of the parties to a pending dispute, and against whom an order of injunction had been passed by a Court of competent jurisdiction.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: in need of amendment.  1  1954 S.C.R. 674. 1060 The petitioners have prayed for an amendment of the original writ petition and also for permission to

arguments.court_reasoning: Selection rests with govt; no evidence of ulterior purpose beyond statutory object; Kedar Nath experienced in industry.

arguments.claim: Petitioner No.1 not legally competent to represent Petitioner No.2 (the company).

anchor.surface_text: In conclusion, it may be stated that on behalf of the authorised Controller a preliminary objection was also taken that petitioner No. 1 was not legally competent to represent petitioner No. 2.

arguments.claim: Conditions in ss.15,16,18A must be read harmoniously; s.18A(1)(b) conditions (investigation under s.15 and detrimental management opinion) relate to period when management vested in owner prior to takeover.

anchor.surface_text: If these ss. 15, 16 and 18A, are read together, as they must be read, then it becomes at once clear that the condition as to the management of the industrial undertaking in a manner highly detrimental to the scheduled industry concerned or to public interest relates in its true scope and effect to a period when the management of the industrial undertaking is in the hands of its owner

arguments.claim: Distinction between functions of control under Essential Supplies Act s.3(4) and full management takeover under IDRA s.18A.

anchor.surface_text: This distinction between exercising certain functions of control, however drastic the functions may be, on an order made under sub-s. (4) of s. 3 of the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act and the taking over of the management of the whole of an undertaking on an order under s. 18A of the Act is a real distinction which must be borne in mind

arguments.claim: s.21 General Clauses Act empowers amendment of s.18A order subject to like conditions, which are fulfilled as they relate to owner-management period subsisting at amendment time.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the amending order is protected under s. 21 of the General Clauses Act read with sub-sec. (1) of s. 18A of the Act. Section 21 of the General Clauses Act says, inter alia, that the power to issue an order under any Central Act includes a power to amend the order but this power is subject to a very important qualification

arguments.claim: Materials existed for Central Govt opinion of detrimental management: ongoing litigation, family disputes, prior investigations recommending takeover.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the circumstances just stated, it is, we think, idle to contend that the Central Government had no materials before it for arriving at the opinion that the industrial undertaking was being managed in a manner highly detrimental to public interest.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: number, however, be heard in time and was later dismissed on May 14, 1954, as having become infructuous in the meantime. On July 30, 1953, the Centra

arguments.court_reasoning: Litigation and disputes continued; prior s.15 investigations and recommendations support opinion.

arguments.claim: Appointment of Kedar Nath Khetan bona fide; govt selects based on suitability and experience; no ulterior purpose shown.

anchor.surface_text: It is sufficient to state that the selection of a suitable person to be the authorised Controller rests with the Central Government and it may be presumed that the Central Government knows best the needs of the particular industry

court_response_anchor.surface_text: in need of amendment.  1  1954 S.C.R. 674. 1060 The petitioners have prayed for an amendment of the original writ petition and also for permission to

arguments.court_reasoning: No evidence of ulterior purpose; experience justifies selection despite disputes.

arguments.claim: s.21 General Clauses Act 'like conditions' refer not to preconditions for issuing order (s.18A(1)(b)), but to conditions the order itself is subject to (e.g., max 5 years duration).

anchor.surface_text: In my view however when s. 21 of the General Clauses Act makes the power to amend exercisable subject to the like conditions as in the main Act, it does not contemplate those conditions upon the fulfillment of which the right to issue the order arises under the main Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: date, i.e., on November 5,1956, when the stay application of the petitioners was heard, the following direction was given by this Court- The hearing

arguments.court_reasoning: Dissent by Sarkar J on interpretation of 'like conditions'; majority holds conditions are s.18A(1)(b) relating to owner period.

holdings.text: The order dated November 8, 1955 is valid under section 18A as there were materials before the Central Government for forming the opinion that the undertaking was being managed in a manner highly detrimental to public interest, following investigation under section 15.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the circumstances just stated, it is, we think, idle to contend that the Central Government had no materials before it for arriving at the opinion that the industrial undertaking was being managed in a manner highly detrimental to public interest.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ongoing family disputes, litigation, prior investigations under s.15 recommending takeover, and insufficiency of prior control orders provided basis for opinion; distinction between control functions and full management takeover.

holdings.text: The conditions in section 18A(1)(b) (prior s.15 investigation and opinion of detrimental management) relate to the period when management is vested in the owner prior to takeover.

anchor.surface_text: If these ss. 15, 16 and 18A, are read together, as they must be read, then it becomes at once clear that the condition as to the management of the industrial undertaking in a manner highly detrimental to the scheduled industry concerned or to public interest relates in its true scope and effect to a period when the management of the industrial undertaking is in the hands of its owner

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious reading of ss.15,16,18A; illogical to apply post-takeover; conditions precedent to takeover.

holdings.text: The amending order dated November 7, 1956 extending the period from one to two years is valid under s.21 General Clauses Act read with s.18A(1), as exercised in like manner and subject to like conditions relating to pre-takeover owner management period which subsisted.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the amending order is protected under s. 21 of the General Clauses Act read with sub-sec. (1) of s. 18A of the Act. Section 21 of the General Clauses Act says, inter alia, that the power to issue an order under any Central Act includes a power to amend the order but this power is subject to a very important qualification

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.21 empowers amendment subject to like conditions; s.18A conditions (s.15 investigation, detrimental management) pertain to owner-vested period and continued to exist; no need for fresh fulfillment for amendment during takeover.

holdings.text: The impugned orders are bona fide; appointment of Shri Kedar Nath Khetan as authorised controller not for ulterior purpose.

anchor.surface_text: It is sufficient to state that the selection of a suitable person to be the authorised Controller rests with the Central Government and it may be presumed that the Central Government knows best the needs of the particular industry

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of ulterior purpose beyond statutory object; government discretion in selection based on experience; test is not judicial re-assessment of suitability.

holdings.text: The orders dated November 8, 1955 and November 7, 1956 are both valid in law; no violation of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we hold that the order made on November 8, 1955, and the amending order dated November 7, 1956, are both valid in law, and the petitioners have not made out any case of a violation of their fundamental right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative conclusion from above determinations on validity, extension, and bona fides; s.18A protected by Art.31B and Ninth Schedule.

holdings.text: Preliminary objection that petitioner No.1 lacks competence to represent petitioner No.2 not decided on merits.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to our decision on merits, it is unnecessary to say anything more about this preliminary objection.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary due to dismissal on merits; suit pending in High Court.

holdings.text: Distinction exists between exercising functions of control under Essential Supplies Act s.3(4) and taking over full management under IDRA s.18A.

anchor.surface_text: This distinction between exercising certain functions of control, however drastic the functions may be, on an order made under sub-s. (4) of s. 3 of the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act and the taking over of the management of the whole of an undertaking on an order under s. 18A of the Act is a real distinction which must be borne in mind

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.18A wider, vests full management; s.3(4) limited to specified control functions; impacts satisfaction of s.18A conditions.

holdings.text: Minority view (Sarkar J.): s.21 General Clauses Act 'like conditions' refer to conditions the order is subject to (e.g., max 5 years duration), not preconditions for issuing order like s.18A(1)(b).

anchor.surface_text: In my view however when s. 21 of the General Clauses Act makes the power to amend exercisable subject to the like conditions as in the main Act, it does not contemplate those conditions upon the fulfillment of which the right to issue the order arises under the main Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Preconditions already allow fresh order; s.21 for amendments during validity; conditions like duration limit apply to amendment.

anchor.surface_text: In December 1953 came the decision of this Court in Dwarkadas Shrinivas of Bombay v. The Sholapur Spinning Weaving Co. Ltd. outcome.relief_summary: Petition under Article 32 dismissed. No merit. Impugned orders dated November 8, 1955 and November 7, 1956 held valid. No violation of fundamental rights found.
